Award.AwardTitle: Structural Properties and Strong Relaxations for Mixed Integer Polynomial Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research in mixed-integer nonlinear optimization has witnessed a significant growth at the theoretical, algorithmic and software levels over the last few years. While these new classes of algorithms have already had a remarkable impact across science, engineering, and economics, there exists a variety of important applications that these methods are unable to address. Compared to linear and convex nonlinear solvers, mixed-integer nonlinear solvers are very slow, cannot handle large-scale problems, and require a high level of user expertise. In fact, many optimization experts believe that in case of nonconvex nonlinear problems, one has to give up on either speed or the guarantee of solution quality. This project aims to address this trade-off, by developing foundational theory to construct strong and tractable polyhedral relaxations for a variety of nonconvex sets that frequently appear as building blocks of nonconvex mixed-integer nonlinear optimization problems. Successful resolution of the research goals of this project will potentially transform solver technology for mixed-integer nonlinear optimization problems; a very powerful framework that subsumes many real-world optimization problems. The project addresses the educational and outreach activities through graduate student mentoring, integration of research results in course work, and broad dissemination of the results of the research.

Factorable programming is a widely-used technique for bounding general nonconvex functions. In particular, factorable reformulations of many nonconvex problems, including quadratic programs, multilinear programs, and polynomial optimization problems, contain a collection of multilinear equations. A main focus of this research is to study the facial structure of the convex hull of a set defined by a system of multilinear equations in the space of the original variables. Through an elegant hypergraph-based representation scheme, various structural properties, decomposition techniques, and lifting operations for such sets will be studied. A rigorous study of the strength and complexity of the relaxations will be performed, and new classes of polynomially-solvable optimization problems will be presented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in nonconvex nonlinear programming (NLP) and mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) has witnessed a significant growth at both theoretical and algorithmic levels over the last few years. While these new classes of algorithms have already had a remarkable impact across science and engineering, there exist a multitude of important applications that these methods are unable to address. Compared to mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) and convex NLP solvers, global solvers are very slow, cannot handle large-scale problems, and require a considerable amount of problem-specific tuning and user expertise. Central to the efficiency of global solvers is their ability to construct sharp and cheaply computable convex relaxations. Factorable programming techniques are used widely in global optimization for bounding general nonconvex functions. These techniques iteratively decompose a factorable function, through the introduction of auxiliary variables for intermediate expressions, until each intermediate constraint can be outer-approximated by a convex feasible set. Current general-purpose global solvers rely on factorable relaxations and as a result, enhancing the quality of such relaxations has a significant impact on our ability to solve a wide range of nonconvex problems.
Factorable reformulations of many types of nonconvex NLPs and MINLPs contain multilinear set defined as a set of binary points satisfying a collection of multilinear equations. Examples include quadratic programs, polynomial programs, and multiplicative programs. We refer to the convex hull of the multilinear set as the multilinear polytope. In the special case where all multilinear terms are bilinears, the multilinear polytope coincides with the Boolean quadric polytope, a well-known polytope in combinatorial optimization. Indeed, a significant amount of research has been devoted to studying the facial structure of the Boolean quadric polytope and these theoretical developments have been highly beneficial for branch-and-cut based algorithms for mixed-integer quadratic optimization problems. However, prior to the completion of this project, similar polyhedral studies for higher degree multilinear polytopes were quite scarce. The main goal of this project was to bridge this gap by performing a systematic study of the facial structure of the multilinear polytope, and thus paving a way for devising novel optimization algorithms for nonconvex problems containing multilinear sub-expressions. In the following, we summarize the main outcomes of this project.
In 'A polyhedral study of binary polynomial programs', we introduced a novel hypergraph representation framework for multilinear sets, which enabled us to derive several families of facet-defining inequalities, and lifting operations for the multilinear polytope in the space of the original variables. 
A great simplification in studying the facial structure of a multilinear polytope is possible when the corresponding multilinear set is decomposable into a collection of simpler multilinear sets. In 'On decomposability of multilinear sets', we studied the decomposability properties of multilinear sets. We derived necessary and sufficient conditions under which a multilinear set is decomposable and we proposed an efficient algorithm to optimally decompose a multilinear set.
Subsequently, in 'The multilinear polytope for acyclic hypergraphs' and 'The running intersection relaxation of the multilinear polytope', we derived explicit characterizations for a wide class of multilinear polytopes by showing that the complexity of the multilinear polytope is closely related to the acyclicity degree of the underlying hypergraph. Namely, optimizing a linear function over the multilinear polytope of certain acyclic hypergraphs can be done in polynomial time. As an important byproduct, we obtained new classes of cutting planes for constructing tighter polyhedral relaxations of MINLPs with multilinear sub-expressions.
In 'On the impact of running intersection inequalities for globally solving polynomial optimization problems', we investigated the impact of the proposed inequalities on the performance of the global solver BARON. We devised an efficient separation algorithm and embedded the proposed cut generation scheme at every node of the branch-and-cut tree. Computational results indicate that new cutting planes lead to an average 50 percent CPU time reduction.
In 'Chvatal rank in binary polynomial optimization', we presented the first results connecting the combinatorial structure of cutting planes for binary polynomial optimization with their Chvatal rank. In particular, we determined the Chvatal rank of all known cutting planes. Next, we introduced odd beta-cycle inequalities, which allowed us to obtain the first characterization of the multilinear polytope for hypergraphs that contain beta-cycles. We also gave sufficient conditions under which odd beta-cycle inequalities can be separated in polynomial-time. Lastly, we performed numerical experiments to test the strength of these inequalities.
In 'On the complexity of binary polynomial optimization over acyclic hypergraphs', we settled the computational complexity of binary polynomial optimization over acyclic hypergraphs. We gave a strongly polynomial-time algorithm for beta-acyclic hypergraphs. Then, we showed that for alpha-acyclic hypergraphs the problem is strongly NP-hard, and NP-hard to approximate within a constant factor provided that P is different from NP. The algorithm can also be applied to simplify any general binary polynomial optimization problem that contains beta-cycles. We assessed the effectiveness of this technique via computational experiments on random hypergraphs.
